description: Possibly related to squirt (“small child”); from 19th c.

entries.meaning: (derogatory, informal, countable) A person of low status.
examples: Not a favourite son, of course — Lord, no! — more a sort of illegitimate backstairs sort of sprog, you know: a sort of spotty squit that nobody really likes.
'Cor blast, Tovell, you don't half talk some squit at times!' exclaimed Ted Carter.

verbs.description: squit (third-person singular simple present squits, present participle squitting, simple past and past participle squitted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Internet) To disconnect (an IRC server) from a network.
examples: […]  these problems solved themselves atfter[sic] some 10 minutes or so, without an ircop interferring[sic] into channel affairs by squitting his/her server to gain chanop status.
